title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: — N that ain't thehalf of it. Boasted tae me, and I lean forward, drilling my thumb intae mychest, — and ah was fifteen at the time, fifteen, for fuck's sake, ah shoutwi a full-on, traumatised gape intae her eyes, — . . . that later on he wentdoon tae Danube Street for a decent hooker, then tae the Shore for a curryand a few lagers. Telt us he still had enough for a gam oaffay a scabbystreetwalker later.

title: The Charming Quirks of Others
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: 'And I heard what was said up there. I came round when she telephoned me a few minutes ago – I live round the corner in Danube Street.' She continued: 'You have to forgive my sister.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: A few days after her return, Mrs. MaxweUGrey drove to Danube Street. Nelly had beenwarned by Janet to expect her, but she had nothad courage to inform Mrs. EUiot that sheintended leaving her service.

title: Bertie's Guide to Life and Mothers
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: They were now getting close to the bridge that crossed the Water of Leith at the end of Danube Street. Off to their left, set up against the edge of Lord Moray's Garden, was a large, quite isolated house, deposited as if an afterthought to the elegant Georgian terraces at the top of the cliff behind it.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: pretty late. NeUy, when she went to bed,had pleasanter things to think of than theparting with the famdy in Danube Street.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Her visits there did her muchharm. They kept her in constant excitement,and disgusted her with the quiet way of Uvingin Danube Street. Mrs. EUiot did not often

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: They now proceeded in sUence, and soonreached Danube Street, which Nelly, who haddried up her tears, viewed with great approba-

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: It was not that she thought ofapplying to her former mistress, but thatshe was most famiUar with that locality. StUl, though with no purpose, as I have said,she went straight on to Danube Street, butwhen she came to the entrance of it shepaused. She looked wistfully along the littlestreet towards Mrs. EUiot's house.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Mrs. EUiot had little opportunity of observing NeUy's conduct for some weeks; herhealth was indifferent; and George had arrivedin Danube Street. He had said fareweU tohis parents, and was to proceed direct toLondon when he left Edinburgh.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Nelly, though a little shy at first, was soonencouraged by Miss EUiot's gentleness, andbefore they reached Danube Street had communicated to her almost aU her little history. She alluded gratefully to Miss Archer's kindness ; but when answering a question of theyoung lady's relating to her parents, the recollection of the sorrowful parting that morning, made her heart so very full that shecould not go on.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: The winter passed away with great quietness. NeUy had by this time almost forgot the formerfreedom she had enjoyed, and was considerablyreconcUed to the sober ways of the family inDanube Street. She now took some pleasurein reading, and, under Martha's superintendence,promised fair to become a steady and valuableservant.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Old Leezie the bowlwoman was aconstant visitor of theirs. Leezie's basketand weU-patched cloak were most convenientreceptacles for aU kinds of household stuff,empty bottles, &c. Twice a week she wassure to caU, not stealing cautiously down thearea steps as formerly in Danube Street,but with a familiar and deliberate tread, asif she knew she was welcome.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: They had been settled for a few days intheir new home, a small but neat house inDanube Street, to which they had got entrance

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: The " term" at length arrived, and NeUywent to her new situation. Before she leftDanube Street, Mrs. EUiot gave her much goodadvice, which, for the time, produced astrong effect on that wayward but impressionable young person. She thought Mrs. EUiot a" saint for goodness," and promised again andagain that she would not forget her warningsor aUow anything to tempt her to neglect herduty.
